answers: negative second power [or negative two; or inverse-square law; or other equivalents; do not accept or prompt on "second power" or "two"]
Laplace–Runge–Lenz vector [or LRL vector; accept Laplace, Runge, or Lenz by themselves or any combination thereof] <Rombro>
parts: Identify this type of force that depends only on the distance between objects and points along the line joining them. The gravitational force and the Coulomb force are examples of this type of force.
The gravitational force and the Coulomb force are both central forces whose magnitude varies with this power of the distance.

In two-body central force problems, this vector, symbolized A, is a constant of the motion. This vector equals momentum cross angular momentum minus m k r-hat, where k is a constant describing the strength of the force.

answers: Francis Picabia [or Francis-Marie Martinez de Picabia] <Thompson>
parts: Name this art movement whose members include Bridget Riley. Many of its paintings, such as Riley's Movement in Squares, are designed to give the viewer an illusion of motion or images that do not exist.
Many of Riley's paintings, including several "untitled" entries in her Fragments series, use only these two colors. Combinations of these two colors are present in monochrome paintings.

This artist's Optophone I may be a precursor to Op art. This French Cubist promoted the works of Man Ray and Marcel Duchamp (dyoo-SHAWM) in his magazine 391, inspired by Alfred Stieglitz's periodical 291.

answers: Book of Numbers [or Bamidbar; or Arithmoi]
parts: Name this prophet whom the king of Moab brought in to curse the Israelites. While riding to meet Balak, his donkey is given the power to speak and complains about this man's treatment.
Balaam's story is mostly recorded in this Old Testament book that follows Leviticus. As its name suggests, it contains a lot of census information.

The Book of Revelation condemns this city in modern-day Turkey for following Balaam's teachings and choosing sexual sins. Part of the seven churches of Asia, this city was where Antipas was martyred and Galen worked in its Asclepium.
What type of building is named in honor of the deceased Captain Alving but was actually only built by his widow to deplete Alving's money so that his son, Oswald, would gain no inheritance?
At the end of the play Ghosts, Oswald wishes to die to end his suffering from this disease.
Ghosts is by this Norwegian author of A Doll's House.

Name this single-reed instrument. Mozart paired it with viola and piano in his "Kegelstatt" (KAY-gul-SHTOTT) Trio, and his final concerto, in A minor, was written for one of these instruments with an extended lower range.
Mozart's Clarinet Concerto and Clarinet Quintet were written for this Austrian virtuoso who also played the basset horn.
The modern system of clarinet fingering was developed by Hyacinthe Klosé (yah-SANT klo-ZAY) and named in tribute of this man, who developed a similar system for the flute.

answers: The Trauma of Birth [or Das Trauma der Geburt]
client-centered therapy [or person-centered therapy; or PCT; or person-centered psychotherapy; or person-centered counseling; prompt on Rogerian psychotherapy] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this 1924 book by an Austrian psychoanalyst. It claims that male homosexuality is caused by men abhorring the female genitals.
This psychologist wrote Inhibitions, Symptoms, and Anxiety in response to Otto Rank's The Trauma of Birth. He wrote The Interpretation of Dreams.
Carl Rogers claimed to be "infected with Rankian ideas," which he said helped him pioneer this type of psychotherapy that requires the therapist to give the patient unconditional positive regard.
Name this poem that opens by declaring that "a wind is ruffling the tawny pelt" of the title continent.
This native of St. Lucia (LOO-sha) wrote "A Far Cry from Africa" and the Homer-inspired epic Omeros.
In the final line of "A Far Cry from Africa," the autobiographical speaker asks, "How can I turn from Africa and [do this action]?"

Give this name, which was also the first name of the president of an African country from 1961 to 1994. That man invented the name of his newly independent country after seeing the name of a lake on an old French map and liking the sound.
Hastings Banda was the first president of this African country, which was formerly known as Nyasaland. During the Cold War, it was the leader of the pro-Western African bloc.
The Soweto uprising occurred in this country, which at the time was still dominated by apartheid policies.

answers: Prokroustes [or Procrustes; or Damastes; or Polypemon; or or Prokoptas; prompt on The Stretcher]
parts: Actually, nothing will, because this hero cleared the road. This hero became king of Athens after he killed the Minotaur but forgot to swap his black sails for white ones.
Thanks to Theseus killing this nightmare host in a poetic manner, you won't get either stretched to death or hacked up to fit this bandit's namesake bed.
You also won't get pulverized by this lame "Clubman" and son of Hephaestus, who used to fatally tenderize passers-by until Theseus beat him to death with his own club.

Name this woman, a model and former showgirl, who was introduced by Stephen Ward to the Secretary of State for War, with whom she had a brief affair that turned scandalous after it was publicly revealed.
This man was the aforementioned Secretary of State for War. After his namesake affair became public, he was forced to resign from the Macmillan ministry.
The Profumo affair took place at the beginning of this decade. Further muddying the waters was the fact that Keeler was also involved with Yevgeny Ivanov, a naval attaché at the Soviet Embassy.

answers: bundle branches [or Tawara branches; prompt on partial answers]
sinoatrial node [or sinus node; or SA node]
parts: Name these fascicles that diverge from a namesake region and conduct electricity to the Purkinje fibers.

Another cause of an extended QRS complex is premature ventricular contraction, which occurs when a cardiac action potential is generated in the Purkinje fibers instead of in this collection of pacemaker cells.

Phase 4 of the cardiac AP is partly maintained by a "leak" current of this ion that decreases as the cells depolarize. The RMP is also kept around this ion's reversal potential by namesake pumps that exchange three sodium ions for two of this ion.

answers: Fanny's child [or Sergeant Troy's child; or baby; or infant; accept obvious equivalents] <Droge>
parts: Name this shepherd who is rejected by Bathsheba Everdene at the start of an 1874 novel, and is the third man in her life alongside Boldwood and Sergeant Troy.
Gabriel Oak is the protagonist of Far from the Madding Crowd, a novel by this author of Jude the Obscure.
While married to Sergeant Troy, Bathsheba is horrified to find this object inside of Fanny Robin's coffin, despite Gabriel's repeated lies to cover up its existence.

answers: a famine [or drought; accept obvious equivalents; prompt on winter]
parts: The best-known mugawar, or Hittite invocation, attempts to entice the fertility god Telipinu to return, since his absence, like that of Demeter, causes one of these events.

Nobody knows why Telipinu left in the first place, but we do know that he's annoyed after being found by one of these animals, to which Virgil compared the Carthaginians under Dido. Book IV of Virgil's Georgics is also about these small animals.

The Hittite text Kingship in Heaven tells of this god overthrowing his father, the sky god Anu. After this god bites off Anu's genitals, this being becomes pregnant and gives birth to Teshub, the storm god, who eventually overthrows him.

answers: Hokkien (hawk-kee-en) [or Taiwanese Hokkien; prompt on Southern Min or Min Nan; anti-prompt (ask "be less specific") on Amoy or Xiamen or Zhangzhou or Quanzhou; do not accept "Hakka"] <Shimizu>
parts: Name this river whose delta is home to a booming economic zone that encompasses Shenzhen (shun-jun), Hong Kong, and Macau.

The emigrants from Sze Yup spoke Taishanese, a dialect of this branch of Chinese named after the city of Guangzhou (gwong-JOH). Speakers of this branch of Chinese oppose Beijing's attempts to impose Mandarin on Guangdong (gwong-dung) province and Hong Kong.

This is the most widespread dialect of southeast China's Min language group. Originally from south Fujian province, it is the basis for Taiwanese and the dialects of the Chinese communities of southeast Asia.

answers: Years of Lead [or Anni di piombo]
Italy [or Kingdom of Italy; or Italian Republic]
Christian Democracy [or CD; or Christian Democrats; or Democrazia Cristiana] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this period that ended around 1982. During it, General James Dozier was kidnapped and 17 people were killed when a bomb exploded at the National Agrarian Bank.
The Years of Lead took place in this European country once led by Benito Mussolini.
During the Years of Lead, Aldo Moro, a former Italian Prime Minister, was kidnapped and killed. Moro was a leader of this party, the largest in the Italian Parliament until 1994.

answers: kidnapping [accept answers such as forcing a free person into slavery; or enslaving a free person; do not accept "impressment"]
parts: Identify this crime prevalent in the early 19th-century United States. A book about this crime described men such as lumber mill owner William Prince Ford and victim Solomon Northup.
Northup spent this many years in slavery. This number appeared in the title of an 1853 memoir he wrote as well as an Oscar-winning 2013 film adaptation.

This city was nicknamed the Fugitive's Gibraltar because of the many slaves who found asylum there, although Herman Melville labeled it a "queer place." The Ernestina is on display at this city's Whaling Museum.

answers: Chinese person [or "The Heathen Chinee"; accept any answer indicating the character is from China; prompt on heathen; prompt on immigrant] <Droge>
parts: Name this story in which John Oakhurst, Mother Shipton, and Uncle Billy are among the title group of people who are exiled from a western town and become trapped in a raging snowstorm.
This author wrote both "The Outcasts of Poker Flat" and "The Luck of Roaring Camp" for the magazine Overland Monthly.

In a Harte story sometimes known as "Plain Language from Truthful James," the character playing cards with James and the amusingly named Bill Nye is one of these people. That character turns out to be a cheat.

answers: molecular orbitals [or MOs; prompt on partial answer]
effective nuclear charge [or Z-effective; or Z-star; prompt on nuclear charge; prompt on Z] <Pendyala>
parts: Name these objects, mathematical representations of electrons delocalized over many atoms. Frontier examples of these objects are analyzed to predict reactivity.

In the linear combination of atomic orbitals, or LCAO, method to generate molecular orbitals, these orbitals formed one of the first linearly combined basis sets. They decay exponentially at large radii, have a cusp at r-equals-zero unlike Gaussian-type orbitals, and have no nodes.

Hartree defined this parameter for Hartree–Fock orbitals to be the mean radius of the hydrogen electron over the mean radius of the valence shell for the atom in question. This parameter can be approximated by subtracting 0.3 or 0.35 for each other electron in the same shell, and subtracting either 0.85 or 1 for electrons in lower shells.

answers: the Soviet Union [or the U.S.S.R.; or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; or Russia; or Russian Federation] <Cheyne>
parts: Name this city, the site of a 1925 film sequence in which soldiers descend an endless flight of steps to attack a crowd, including a mother pushing a baby carriage and a nurse with broken glasses.
The Odessa Steps sequence appears in this Sergei Eisenstein film that documents a 1905 naval mutiny aboard the title ship.
Eisenstein was a director from this country, whose other filmmakers include Andrei Tarkovsky.

answers: arithmetic sequence [or arithmetic progression; do not accept "arithmetic series"] <Thompson>
parts: Identify this theorem that relates the product of the Legendre (luh-JOND-ruh) symbols of p and q with that of q and p for odd primes p and q. This result can be used to decide whether a solution exists to the equation x-squared is congruent to a modulo p, where p is an odd prime.
If c is a quadratic residue modulo p, then c raised to the power p-minus-one over two is congruent to one, according to this man's namesake little theorem.

The law of quadratic reciprocity can be used to prove certain cases of Dirichlet's (dee-ree-CLAY's) theorem, which states that this type of sequence contains infinitely many primes if its first term is relatively prime with its common difference.

answers: Pius XI [or Ambrogio Damiano Achille Ratti]
parts: Name this pope who issued the encyclical Mit brennender Sorge (mit BREN-in-duh ZOR-guh), or "With burning concern," which was secretly smuggled into Germany and preached on Palm Sunday.

Pius XI's Divini Redemptoris condemned this type of government, especially that espoused by the Bolsheviks, for being atheistic. His successor, Pius XII, was opposed to the Italian party that advocated for this form of government.
Pius XII issued the encyclical Summi Pontificatus to decry events in this country. The Soviets killed people from this country in the Katyn Forest massacre.
